trans-unit.source: Create and upload a Linux VHD in Azure
trans-unit.target: Create and upload a Linux VHD in Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn to create and upload an Azure virtual hard disk (VHD) that contains the Linux operating system.
trans-unit.target: Learn to create and upload an Azure virtual hard disk (VHD) that contains the Linux operating system.

trans-unit.source: Creating and Uploading a Virtual Hard Disk that Contains the Linux Operating System
trans-unit.target: Creating and Uploading a Virtual Hard Disk that Contains the Linux Operating System

trans-unit.source: This article shows you how to create and upload a virtual hard disk (VHD) so you can use it as your own image to create virtual machines in Azure.
trans-unit.target: This article shows you how to create and upload a virtual hard disk (VHD) so you can use it as your own image to create virtual machines in Azure.

trans-unit.source: You'll learn how to prepare the operating system so you can use it to create multiple virtual machines based on that image.
trans-unit.target: You'll learn how to prepare the operating system so you can use it to create multiple virtual machines based on that image.

trans-unit.source: Note that this article refers to virtual machines created using the classic deployment model.
trans-unit.target: Note that this article refers to virtual machines created using the classic deployment model.

trans-unit.source: A virtual machine in Azure runs the operating system that's based on the image you choose when you create the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: A virtual machine in Azure runs the operating system that's based on the image you choose when you create the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Your images are stored in VHD format, in .vhd files in a storage account.
trans-unit.target: Your images are stored in VHD format, in .vhd files in a storage account.

trans-unit.source: For details, see <link><linkText>About Disks and Images in Azure</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For details, see <link><linkText>About Disks and Images in Azure</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: When you create the virtual machine, you can customize some of the operating system settings so they're appropriate for the application you want to run.
trans-unit.target: When you create the virtual machine, you can customize some of the operating system settings so they're appropriate for the application you want to run.

trans-unit.source: For instructions, see <link><linkText>How to Create a Custom Virtual Machine</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For instructions, see <link><linkText>How to Create a Custom Virtual Machine</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Important: The Azure platform SLA applies to virtual machines running the Linux OS only when one of the endorsed distributions is used with the configuration details as specified under 'Supported Versions' in Linux on Azure-Endorsed Distributions.
trans-unit.target: Important: The Azure platform SLA applies to virtual machines running the Linux OS only when one of the endorsed distributions is used with the configuration details as specified under 'Supported Versions' in Linux on Azure-Endorsed Distributions.

trans-unit.source: All Linux distributions in the Azure image gallery are endorsed distributions with the required configuration.
trans-unit.target: All Linux distributions in the Azure image gallery are endorsed distributions with the required configuration.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: This article assumes that you have the following items:
trans-unit.target: This article assumes that you have the following items:

trans-unit.source: A management certificate - You have created a management certificate for the subscription for which you want to upload a VHD, and exported the certificate to a .cer file.
trans-unit.target: A management certificate - You have created a management certificate for the subscription for which you want to upload a VHD, and exported the certificate to a .cer file.

trans-unit.source: For more information about creating certificates, see <link><linkText>Create and Upload a Management Certificate for Azure</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about creating certificates, see <link><linkText>Create and Upload a Management Certificate for Azure</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Linux operating system installed in a .vhd file - You have installed a supported Linux operating system to a virtual hard disk.
trans-unit.target: Linux operating system installed in a .vhd file - You have installed a supported Linux operating system to a virtual hard disk.

trans-unit.source: Multiple tools exist to create .vhd files, for example you can use a virtualization solution such as Hyper-V to create the .vhd file and install the operating system.
trans-unit.target: Multiple tools exist to create .vhd files, for example you can use a virtualization solution such as Hyper-V to create the .vhd file and install the operating system.

trans-unit.source: For instructions, see <link><linkText>Install the Hyper-V Role and Configure a Virtual Machine</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For instructions, see <link><linkText>Install the Hyper-V Role and Configure a Virtual Machine</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Important: The newer VHDX format is not supported in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Important: The newer VHDX format is not supported in Azure.

trans-unit.source: You can convert the disk to VHD format using Hyper-V Manager or the convert-vhd cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: You can convert the disk to VHD format using Hyper-V Manager or the convert-vhd cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: For a list of endorsed distributions, see <link><linkText>Linux on Azure-Endorsed Distributions</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For a list of endorsed distributions, see <link><linkText>Linux on Azure-Endorsed Distributions</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, see the section at the end of this article for <link><linkText>Information for Non-Endorsed Distributions</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, see the section at the end of this article for <link><linkText>Information for Non-Endorsed Distributions</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Azure Command-line Interface - if you are using a Linux operating system to create your image, you use the Azure Command-Line Interface to upload the VHD.
trans-unit.target: Azure Command-line Interface - if you are using a Linux operating system to create your image, you use the Azure Command-Line Interface to upload the VHD.

trans-unit.source: Azure Powershell tools - the Add-AzureVhd cmdlet can also be used to upload the VHD.
trans-unit.target: Azure Powershell tools - the Add-AzureVhd cmdlet can also be used to upload the VHD.

trans-unit.source: See <link><linkText>Azure Downloads</linkText><title></title></link> to download the Azure Powershell cmdlets.
trans-unit.target: See <link><linkText>Azure Downloads</linkText><title></title></link> to download the Azure Powershell cmdlets.

trans-unit.source: For reference information, see <link><linkText>Add-AzureVhd</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For reference information, see <link><linkText>Add-AzureVhd</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: <html></html> <html></html>Step 1: Prepare the image to be uploaded
trans-unit.target: <html></html> <html></html>Step 1: Prepare the image to be uploaded

trans-unit.source: Azure supports a variety of Linux distributions (see <link><linkText>Endorsed Distributions</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Azure supports a variety of Linux distributions (see <link><linkText>Endorsed Distributions</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: The following articles will guide you through how to prepare the various Linux distributions that are supported on Azure:
trans-unit.target: The following articles will guide you through how to prepare the various Linux distributions that are supported on Azure:

trans-unit.source: **<link><linkText>CentOS-based Distributions</linkText><title></title></link>**
trans-unit.target: **<link><linkText>CentOS-based Distributions</linkText><title></title></link>**

trans-unit.source: **<link><linkText>Oracle Linux</linkText><title></title></link>**
trans-unit.target: **<link><linkText>Oracle Linux</linkText><title></title></link>**

trans-unit.source: **<link><linkText>SLES & openSUSE</linkText><title></title></link>**
trans-unit.target: **<link><linkText>SLES & openSUSE</linkText><title></title></link>**

trans-unit.source: **<link><linkText>Ubuntu</linkText><title></title></link>**
trans-unit.target: **<link><linkText>Ubuntu</linkText><title></title></link>**

trans-unit.source: **<link><linkText>Other - Non-Endorsed Distributions</linkText><title></title></link>**
trans-unit.target: **<link><linkText>Other - Non-Endorsed Distributions</linkText><title></title></link>**

trans-unit.source: Also see the **<link><linkText>Linux Installation Notes</linkText><title></title></link>** for more tips on preparing Linux images for Azure.
trans-unit.target: Also see the **<link><linkText>Linux Installation Notes</linkText><title></title></link>** for more tips on preparing Linux images for Azure.

trans-unit.source: After following the steps in the guides above you should have a VHD file that is ready to upload into Azure.
trans-unit.target: After following the steps in the guides above you should have a VHD file that is ready to upload into Azure.

trans-unit.source: <html></html> <html></html>Step 2: Prepare the connection to Azure
trans-unit.target: <html></html> <html></html>Step 2: Prepare the connection to Azure

trans-unit.source: Before you can upload a .vhd file, you need to establish a secure connection between your computer and your subscription in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Before you can upload a .vhd file, you need to establish a secure connection between your computer and your subscription in Azure.

trans-unit.source: If using Azure CLI
trans-unit.target: If using Azure CLI

trans-unit.source: Use Azure AD method to login:
trans-unit.target: Use Azure AD method to login:

trans-unit.source: Open an Azure CLI window
trans-unit.target: Open an Azure CLI window

trans-unit.source: Type:
trans-unit.target: Type:

trans-unit.source: azure login
trans-unit.target: azure login

trans-unit.source: When prompted, type your username and password.
trans-unit.target: When prompted, type your username and password.

trans-unit.source: OR, use a PublishSettings file instead:
trans-unit.target: OR, use a PublishSettings file instead:

trans-unit.source: Open an Azure CLI window
trans-unit.target: Open an Azure CLI window

trans-unit.source: Type:
trans-unit.target: Type:

trans-unit.source: azure account download
trans-unit.target: azure account download

trans-unit.source: This command opens a browser window and automatically downloads a .publishsettings file that contains information and a certificate for your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: This command opens a browser window and automatically downloads a .publishsettings file that contains information and a certificate for your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: Save the .publishsettings file
trans-unit.target: Save the .publishsettings file

trans-unit.source: Type:
trans-unit.target: Type:

trans-unit.source: azure account import
trans-unit.target: azure account import

trans-unit.source: Where is the full path to the .publishsettings file.
trans-unit.target: Where is the full path to the .publishsettings file.

trans-unit.source: For more information, read <link><linkText>Connect to Azure from Azure CLI</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, read <link><linkText>Connect to Azure from Azure CLI</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: If using Azure PowerShell
trans-unit.target: If using Azure PowerShell

trans-unit.source: Use Azure AD method to login:
trans-unit.target: Use Azure AD method to login:

trans-unit.source: Open an Azure PowerShell window.
trans-unit.target: Open an Azure PowerShell window.

trans-unit.source: Type:
trans-unit.target: Type:

trans-unit.source: Add-AzureAccount
trans-unit.target: Add-AzureAccount

trans-unit.source: When prompted, enter your organizational user id and password.
trans-unit.target: When prompted, enter your organizational user id and password.

trans-unit.source: OR, use the PublishSettings files instead:
trans-unit.target: OR, use the PublishSettings files instead:

trans-unit.source: Open an Azure PowerShell window.
trans-unit.target: Open an Azure PowerShell window.

trans-unit.source: Type:
trans-unit.target: Type:

trans-unit.source: Get-AzurePublishSettingsFile
trans-unit.target: Get-AzurePublishSettingsFile

trans-unit.source: This command opens a browser window and automatically downloads a .publishsettings file that contains information and a certificate for your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: This command opens a browser window and automatically downloads a .publishsettings file that contains information and a certificate for your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: Save the .publishsettings file.
trans-unit.target: Save the .publishsettings file.

trans-unit.source: Type:
trans-unit.target: Type:

trans-unit.source: Import-AzurePublishSettingsFile
trans-unit.target: Import-AzurePublishSettingsFile

trans-unit.source: Where is the full path to the .publishsettings file.
trans-unit.target: Where is the full path to the .publishsettings file.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link><linkText>How to install and configure Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link><linkText>How to install and configure Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: We recommend you use the newer Azure Active Directory method to login to your Azure subscription, either from the Azure CLI or the Azure PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: We recommend you use the newer Azure Active Directory method to login to your Azure subscription, either from the Azure CLI or the Azure PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: <html></html> <html></html>Step 3: Upload the image to Azure
trans-unit.target: <html></html> <html></html>Step 3: Upload the image to Azure

trans-unit.source: If using Azure CLI
trans-unit.target: If using Azure CLI

trans-unit.source: Use the Azure CLI to upload the image.
trans-unit.target: Use the Azure CLI to upload the image.

trans-unit.source: You can upload an image by using the following command:
trans-unit.target: You can upload an image by using the following command:

trans-unit.source: If using PowerShell
trans-unit.target: If using PowerShell

trans-unit.source: You will need a storage account to upload your VHD file to.
trans-unit.target: You will need a storage account to upload your VHD file to.

trans-unit.source: You can either pick an existing one or create a new one.
trans-unit.target: You can either pick an existing one or create a new one.

trans-unit.source: To create a storage account please refer to <link><linkText>Create a Storage Account</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: To create a storage account please refer to <link><linkText>Create a Storage Account</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: When you upload the .vhd file, you can place the .vhd file anywhere within your blob storage.
trans-unit.target: When you upload the .vhd file, you can place the .vhd file anywhere within your blob storage.

trans-unit.source: In the following command examples, BlobStorageURL is the URL for the storage account you plan to use, YourImagesFolder is the container within blob storage where you want to store your images.
trans-unit.target: In the following command examples, BlobStorageURL is the URL for the storage account you plan to use, YourImagesFolder is the container within blob storage where you want to store your images.

trans-unit.source: VHDName is the label that appears in the Management Portal to identify the virtual hard disk.
trans-unit.target: VHDName is the label that appears in the Management Portal to identify the virtual hard disk.

trans-unit.source: PathToVHDFile is the full path and name of the .vhd file.
trans-unit.target: PathToVHDFile is the full path and name of the .vhd file.

trans-unit.source: From the Azure PowerShell window you used in the previous step, type:
trans-unit.target: From the Azure PowerShell window you used in the previous step, type:

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Add-AzureVhd]((https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn495173.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Add-AzureVhd]((https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn495173.aspx).
